div.head: THE EGYPTIAN GAZETTE
No. 7239] ALEXANDRIA, THURSDAY, JULY 13, 1905. [SIX PAGES P.T. 1.
THE BALTIC FLEET
VIGILANCE
LOOKING OUT FOR THE JAPS
div.p: SANPAKAN, January 11.
Two Japanese transports were at Labuan on the scouting work. (Reuter.)
LABUAN, January 11
Two colliers for Russia arrived here on the 7th inst. (Reuter.)
Port Louise (Mauritius), January 11.

It is rumored that the Japanese Fleet has reached Diego Garcia. Admiral Rodjestvensky was informed on the 2nd inst. that the Japanee were proceeding to meet the Baltic Fleet. The Russians redoubled their vigilance. One of Admiral Rodjestvensky's aides-de-camp, interviewed at Tamatave on the 3rd inst., said the squadron would require one month in order to cross the Indian Ocean. (Reuter.)

div.head: INTERNATIONAL AMENITIES.
KAISER AND THE GENERALS.
div.p: Berlin, January 11.

Emperor, in asking the assent of the Tsar and the Mikado to the granting of the order of merit to Generals Stoessel and Nogi, telegraphed to the Tsar. "The defence of Port Arthur will ever be an example to soldiers of all nations. The hero commanding your troops is admired by the whole world and especially by my army and myself. I am conferring the same honor on his brave opponent.

The Kaiser also telegraphed to the Mikado: "The siege of Port Arthur has shown General Nogi to be a brave and prudent commander, whose heroic deeds, and those of his troops will ever be shared by all soldiers, and especially by myself and my army. His brave opponent is receiving the same distinction.
The Tsar replied that he highly appreciated the sympathy of the Kaiser and his army. General Stoessel has gallantly done his duty to the end at the head of hi brave garrison.
The Mikado replied that he was much by his Majesty's admiration for the of Port Arthur, and assented with the Kaiser's and wish to confer on in the Prussian. (Reuter.)

div.head: ADMIRAL SKRYDLOFF
LEAVES ST. PETERSBURG
div.p: January 11.
St. Petersburg. (Reuter.)

div.head: BLOODY RUSSIAN STRIKES
BLOODSHED
div.p: Baki, January 11.
(Reuter.)

div.head: STRIKE AT ESSEX
20,000 MINERS OUT.
div.p: Essex, January 11.
miners of the Ruhr basin have strike. (Havas.)

div.head: THE BETHLEHEM DISTURBANCE.
INCENSED ECCLESIASTICS.
div.p: Jerusalem, January 11.

Besides the Italian monk wounded during the affray at Bethlehem, a German Franciscan was also injured. The Consuls of both nations are taking vigorous measures to secure the punishment of the Greek ecclesiastics. The latter's weapons during the disturbance were censers. (Reuter.)

div.head: AMERICA AND CHINA.
CANCELLATION OF RAILWAY CONCESSION.
div.p: Washington, January 11.

The American Government has informed China that it disapproves of the proposed cancellation of the concession for the Hankau and Canton Railway, and that it regards the concessionaires as entitles to the protection of the American-Government. (Reuter.)

div.head: AMERICAN TARIFF.
PROPOSED RE-ADJUSTMENT.
div.p: Washington, January 11.
President Roosevelt strongly advocates a special session of congress for the re-adjustment of the tariff. It is unlikely that the session will be held before the autumn. (Reuter.)

div.head: VATICAN AND QUIRINAL.
A SIGNIFICANT EVENT.
div.p: Rome, January 11.
The Pope has received in audience the Duke and Duchess of Genoa. This is the first time that a Prince belonging to the House of Savoy has entered the Vatican. (Reuter.)

div.head: THE COMBES MINISTRY.
A DECLARED OPPONENT.
div.p: Paris, January 11.
M. Doumer, addressing a meeting of the Radical Left prior to his election, declared that every opportunity must be taken to subject the Ministry to a reverse. (Reuter.)

div.head: FRANCE AND MOROCCO.
SULTAN POWERLESS.
div.p: Tangier, January 11.
M. St. René Taillandier embarked to-day en route for Fez, viâ Laraiche, the Sultan being powerless to guarantee the safety of the direct route from Tangier to Fez. (Reuter.)

div.head: ADEN HINTERLAND.
IRADE REJECTED.
div.p: London, January 11.
Great Britain has rejected the Irade concerning the Aden hinterland, and insists on a settlement on the basis of the assurances previously given. (Reuter.)
The Steam Yacht "Argonaut" left Alexandria yesterday for Naples and Marseilles.
Khedivial Ball. A notice in yesterday's Journal announced that the Khedive’s annual State ball will take place at Abdeen Palace on Friday, 20th inst.

A Pleasure Trip Stopped.—A native of Elfu, who was in the service of Radwan Eff., of the Khalifa district, Cairo, being desirous of a few days' enjoyment at his master's expense, induced a son of his employer to steal from his father a small cash-box, containing £70, a diamond earring, and several other valuables. With this in their possession the two started on their trip: The father quickly apprised the police, who telegraphed to the various moudiriehs a description of the delinquents. The latter had made for Edfu, but on their way alighted at Keneh, in order to spend some of their money there. Here they attracted the attention of a detective and were arrested by him. Having part of the stolen money well as the diamond earring in their possession, there was no doubt as to their identity, and they were soon sent back to Cairo in custody.
Our Constantinople Correspondent states that Count Batthyany, president of the Jockey Club, of Budapest, who is now at Constantinople, is leaving for Egypt and Syria on a special mission shortly.

The latest arrivals at Shepheard's Hotel include Col. Henry Pasha, Major Baumann and party, Baron von Konig, Mr. Quellenec, Messrs. Bonnet, Comte B. Tyszkiewicz, Mr. von Schoeler, Mr. Empain, the well-known Belgian financier, Freiherr S. von Cannstatt Oberstleutnant von Willing, Baron A. Mylins, Baron Pidoll, Baron and Baroness Reedly Thott, Count Luttichan, Mr. and Mrs. Honigmann, Mr. and Miss G. de Thierry, Messrs. Lewison and Miller, etc.

div.head: DESCRIPTION OF ARRIVAL.
PRESENCE OP RUSSIAN SPIES.
PARTICULARS OF VESSELS.
div.p: (From our Special Correspondent).
Port Said, Tuesday.

The long-expected squadron has at last arrived here. Though due to arrive at dawn, and passed in the night by the British S.S. “Scot,” a ship of 10 knots which arrived here at 10 a.m., the fleet was not off the port until 2.30 p.m. The P. and O. mail steamer “Egypt" arrived oft the port at the same time, and had to give precedence to the warships, but no doubt the interesting event compensated the. passengers for the delay.

The day was fine and bright, a light northwest wind was blowing, and the sea was smooth ; but notwithstanding this the two protected cruisers of the fleet rolled heavily, even when, to some extent, under the lee of the breakwater. This defect has been noticeable in nearly all the Russian warships that have passed through the canal, and it must be a serious handicap to their gunnery practice in a seaway.

A considerable number of people gathered along the front to watch the passage of the ships, and many cameras were in evidence, the probability of most of these ships being sent to the bottom before long no doubt acting as an incentive to collect souvenirs.

A large number of Russian spies have been noticed in the town for some days. Weird, unkempt-looking individuals, they loaf about the cafés in an aimless way, day and night, doing nothing, for there is certainly not the slightest work for them to do here. Precautionary measures have, it is true, been taken by the authorities ; but not to the same elaborate extent as before, and the spirit of the officers in charge of these duties is that of an amused participator in a harmless pantomine.

The first vessels of the fleet to enter the harbour were two of the destroyers, followed closely by the flagship "Oreg.” Another destroyer followed, then came the second-class cruiser "Izumrund,” followed by the Volunteer Fleet ships "Rion” and ‘‘Dnieper.’’ These last two vessels are, respectively, our old friends the "Smolensk" and “Petersburg,” which passed the Dardanelles under the merchant and Red Cross flags and seized, amongst other ships, the P. and O. steamer “Malacca.” The new names they bear, and the coat of dark grey paint, are no doubt a concession to England’s vigorous protest, followed by the demonstration made in these waters in July last by eight battleships of our Mediterranean Squadron, on account of the breach of the Treaty of Paris.

The "Rion” and “Dnieper” look smart and well-kept, but the “Oreg” and “Izumrud,” notwithstanding the fact that they are comparatively new ships, look rather seedy, and do not strike one as having been in dry-dock of late.
The fleet will prove a useful reinforcement to Admiral Rodjestvensky, for, as will be seen from the following particulars, they are all fast and well-armed ships :—
“Oreg.” Flagship. 1st class protected cruiser. Speed 23 knots. Guns: 12 six inch, 12 three-inch, 8 three pounders, 2 1 pounders. Two submerged torpedo tubes, and 2 torpedo tubes above water-line.
“Izumrud. ’ 2nd class protected cruiser. Speed 22.5 knots. Guns : 6 4 7, 8 three-pounders, 5 torpedo tubes above water line.
“Rion.” Speed 19 1/2 knots. Guns : 8 4 7, 8 three-pounders, 4 one-pounder, 2 Maxims.
“Dnieper. ’ Speed 19.5 knots. Guns: 8 4 7., 6 3-inch, 3 Maxims.
Three destroyers of similar class, 350 tons diplacement each. Speed 26 knots.

From these details it will be seen that the fleet is a scouting, rather than a fighting, force, two of the cruisers having no protection whatever. The other two, having only armoured decks and gun shields, could not hope to successfully engage the powerful armoured cruisers of Japan.

div.head: ARRIVAL AT SUEZ.
div.p: (From Our Own Correspondent).
Suez, Wednesday, (7.15 p m.).

The Russian Squadron has arrived at Ismailia. The destroyers have anchored for the night and will proceed at daybreak. The cruisers are continuing their voyage and will arrive at Suez at daybreak, the destroyers in the forenoon.
Suez, Thursday, (8.30 a.m.).
Four cruisers arrived here at 5 o’clock to-day and anchored in the bay. The torpedo boats will arrive at 10 o'clock in the forenoon.
Suez, Thursday, (9.30 a.m.).
Three destroyers have arrived here and anchored alongside the cruisers. All of them are fitted with wireless telegraphy apparatus. The Squadron has applied for provisions and liquors.

div.head: ESTABLISHMENT OF NEW BANK.
div.p: (From our own Correspondent).
Constantinople, January 5.

A new financial establishment, to be styled the Orient Bank, has been founded by the Banque Nationale of Athens and the National Bank of Berlin. The statutes of this bank have already been published in the “Official Gazette” at Athens. Agencies will be opened very shortly at Alexandria, Constantinople, and Smyrna, probably at the end of the next month. The well-known local banker, M. Zarifi, has accepted the post of adviser to the bank.

Contrary to what was announced, it is now stated that no shares whatsoever are to be issued, the capital of ten million francs having been wholly subscribed by the two banks interested, the National of Greece and the National of Berlin.

The manager of the Hellenic National Bank has arrived here from Athens, where he was lately received by King George, who expressed his satisfaction at the co-operation of the two banks. The agency in Constantinople will be placed under the superintendence of a committee composed of M. E. Engénidés, M. S. Zarifi, and M. T. Mavrogordato, of our city.
A London financial correspondent sends us the following information on the same subject:

—Considerable interest attaches to the formation of the “Orient Bank" by the National-bank fur Deutschland and the Banque Nationale de Gréce. The capital will be Fr. 10,000,000 (gold), of which each of the founder institutions takes one-half. The seat of the new bank will be Athens, but its chief field of operations will be Turkey, Asia Minor, and Egypt, its principal business the financing of the export and import trade. It is believed that the assistance of the German institution will be of special value in Turkey, where German influence is at present paramount.

div.head: LAND BANK OF EGYPT.
div.p: The Board of Directors of the new Land Bank of Egypt is composed as follows : Chairman : Mr. Ambroise Zervudachi; Directors: Messrs. Joseph Aghion, J. E. Cornish, Michel Salvago, Georges Zervudachi, Richard C. Abdy, Augustin Feraud, chairman of the Société Marseillaise de Crédit Industriel et Commercial et de Dépôts, Jules Charles Roux, Vice-President of the Suez Canal Company, Periclés Zarifi, administrator of the Société Marseillaise de Crédit Commercial et Industriel et de Dépôts.

The head office of the bank will be at Alexandria. The capital is £500,000, composed of 95,000 ordinary shares of £5 each and 5,000 deferred shares of £5 each. The capital has been subscribed as follows:—

The Anglo-Foreign Bank- Ordinary Deferred ing Co. Ld 2,500 119 P. P. Salvago and Co... 23,000 1,054 C. G. Zervudachi and fils... 24,000 1,054 Total 95,000 5,000

div.head: A LANDLORD’S JOKE.
div.p: Last June Mohamed Said Pasha, wekil of the Daira of Sheikh Ibrahim Pasha, issued the following notice on behalf of the estate, which was published in all the newspapers of Alexandria ;—

Sheikh Mohamed Said Pasha, wekil of the Daira of the late Sheikh Ibrahim Pasha, informs the public that, in view of the popular complaints against the in-increase of the rents in Alexandria, of the smallness and paucity of business at present, and of the duty of all honorable people in the common interest and of the benevolent feelings which should animate this question, the family of the late Sheikh Ibrahim Pasha have decided, in the interests of humanity and in solicitude for the poor, not to increase the rents of their property.

The generosity of this brought forth a great deal of laudation, as such conduct was so different from that which generally characterises the Alexandrian landlord. The moderation and philanthropy were praised to the skies and the course adopted was pointed out as an example to others. The Sheikh promised the Tenants Commission that he would also do his best to urge other landlords to exercise the same moderation.

This, however, appears to have been a practical joke on the part of the owner, for they have recently informed their tenants that their rents would be raised, and the additions that are being made to the rents are furthermore very excessive.

div.head: STEAMER MOVEMENTS.
div.p: The Cunard S.S. "Tyria’’ sailed direct for Liverpool early this morning with a full Cargo.

div.head: CAIRO TOURIST SEASON.
PROMISES TO BE A RECORD ONE
div.p: We are informed that the managers of the hotels in the Capital, as well as at Helouan, Mena House, and up-river, are jubilant at the large number and class of tourists that are already crowding all the winter resorts of Egypt, and there are unmistakable signs in all directions that the present will prove to be the record season, surpassing even the last, which was considered the best so far.

As an instance, we may say that at one of the leading Cairo hotels,—the Grand Continental,—there was a daily average during the month of November of no less than 120 visitora more than during the corresponding month of the previous year, and for December the daily number was even greater. Shepheard’s has been crowded for weeks, and the other fashionable hostelries, the Savoy and Ghezireh Palace Hotels, are also filling up rapidly.

The smaller hotels everywhere report the same good news, and the managers aver that never before have their houses been full so early, despite the large number of tourists that have already left for the Nile trip and Khartoum.

div.head: THE SAKHARA INCIDENT.
div.p: In regard to the stories about the attack on some tourists by Bedouins at Sakhara which have been appearing in the Cairo newspapers, we hear on high authority that there is a good deal to be said on the other side. An official enquiry is about to be held, and we will refrain from commenting on the affair as it is sub-justice. Some of our contemporaries seem to us to have been a little too hasty in assuming that the fault was entirely on one side.

div.head: COUNCIL OF MINISTERS.
div.p: The Council of Ministers met this morning at Abdeen Palace under the presidency of the Khedive to consider the projet de loi concerning the Assize Courts.

div.head: REGISTRATION OF DOGS.
div.p: We hear that the new regulations for the registration of dogs are almost completed. We welcome the news and hope that no misguided Europeans will attempt to take shelter behind the Capitulations, and to avoid compliance with a measure dictated by common prudence.

div.head: MINISTRY OF PUBLIC INSTRUCTION.
div.p: We would desire to draw attention to the prominence given to the Ministry of Public instruction in the Note recently published by the Financial Adviser. The budget for 1905 has been increased by L.E 31,300 over that of 1904. This is a gratifying feature and, with out doubt, will tend towards a general improvement of the education of the country. Hitherto young educated Egyptians have found it more profitable to pursue their higher studies for qualification in Medicine, Law, and the more liberal professions. Teaching as a profession did not seem to offer many adequate prizes ; but we have no hesitation in stating that a perusal of the table of salaries issued by the Ministry will turn the thoughts of many Egyptian parents towards the adoption of the teaching profession for their sons.

From this table we observe that L.E.16,360, which represents the sum specified in the Financial Adviser's Note for the improvement in the status of the staff, together with other money disposable for the same purpose, or rather more than half the total increase of the budget for 1905, will be devoted to advance the position of such officials as are engaged in school-work. To this substantial addition must also be added the increases of salary accorded by the Ministry each year in the month of January.

Admission to the higher posts held by teachers is by means of the Training Colleges. Native inspectors and sub-inspectors of kuttabs are drawn from the Nasrieh Training College ; while attendance at the Training College for English-speaking natives opens the way to the headmasterships of Primary schools. We would particularly call attention to the greatly improved prospects of the headmasters and senior teachers in Primary schools.

div.head: CAIRO DEACONESSES’ HOSPITAL.
div.p: The many alterations and improvements that have been carried out during the past few months at the above hospital, and which it was hoped would have been completed by the 1st December last, will not be finished for another month or so, the delay having been caused by the native workmen employed. The whole of the masonry work in connection with the second floor that has been added to the hospital is now finished, and the plasterers, painters, and carpenters are busy completing the remaining work, but it is not intended to open the new wards before the 1st April, so as to allow time for them to dry thoroughly before admitting patients. In the mean while the old 1st and 2nd class wards on the first floor, which had been closed for some months during the building operations, have been reopened to paying patients. The new lift will also be in operation by the latter date.

The additions to the building include fourteen rooms, which will be reserved exclusively in future for paying patients of European nationality, and the old wards will then be retained for natives. On the second storey there will be likewise a new special operating-room , fitted with all the latest improvements. This was needed in consequence of the great increase in the number of operations during the past few years.

div.head: THE POPE AND THE SULTAN.
div.p: (From our Correspondent ).
Constantinople, January 6.

H.B. Mgr. Cyril, Greek-Catholic Patriarch at Alexandria, has sent an address of gratitude to the Sultan for the Imperial alms distributed every year on Christmas and New Year’s Day to the poor of the Melchite community. In the letter of the Pope, which the Patriarch conveyed to the Sultan, the Holy Father expressed his thanks for the favors enjoyed by Catholics in the Ottoman Empire.

div.head: MARQUIS DI RUDINI’S TRIP.
div.p: (From our own Correspondent.)
Luxor, Tuesday.

The Marquis di Rudini arrived here this morning by the “train de luxe.” He was met at the station by the Italian consular agent here, Mr. Endraons, who accompanied him to the Luxor Hotel, where the Italian Minister is staying. Marquis di Rudini spent the day strolling round the city and visiting the ruins of Karnak. To-morrow he will go to see Thebes and the Tombs of the Kings. On Thursday morning he is proceeding to Assouan, and from thence to Khartoum. He is expected back at Assouan on the 28th inst. After returning to Cairo his Excellency intends going on to Erythrea, where he will make a lengthy tour with Marquis Talamo.

div.head: LEGISLATIVE COUNCIL.
div.p: (From our own Correspondent).
Keneh, Thursday.

Hassan Bakry Bey and Ibrahim Aly Bey have come to the top of the poll in the election for two members to represent Keneh Moudirieh on the Legislative Council. The former polled 68 and the latter 50 votes. The Sub-Moudir presided at the sitting. The Moudir maintained order.

div.head: MEHKEMEH SHARIEH.
div.p: By Khedivial decree the Supreme Mehkemeh Sharieh has been reconstituted. It will be composed of the Grand Cadi as President, and the members will be four in number, who will be proposed by the Ministry of Justice and appointed by the Khedive.

div.head: THE KHEDIVE.
div.p: The Khedive spent yesterday morning at Koubbeh Palace. In the afternoon his Highness visited bis estates at Moustouroud.
This morning his Highness proceeded to Abdeen Palace to preside at the Council of Ministers.

div.head: ZIZINIA THEATRE.
div.p: There was a large house at the Zizinia theatre last night for the third performance ot Giordano's new opera, “Siberia.” The audience, however, appeared, as on the previous occasions, to be affected by the coldness of the surroundings. The interpretation was good, especially as regards Signora Amelia Pinto in the role of Stephana and the baritone Nani as Gleby. The chorus was better than ever, the Siberian exiles’ chorus, in particular, being exceedingly well rendered. The orchestra was excellent.

div.head: VERDI THEATRE, CAIRO.
div.p: The Verdi Theatre was the scene on Tuesday of a most delightful performance of “The Barber of Seville.” The house was well filled, and all the actors took the keenest interest in their parts, with the result that a most successful ensemble was ensured. Signora Svicher again astonished us all by her wonderful vocalism. She seems to possess no less than three octaves in her voice, and every note is taken with ease and clearness : her singing was a marvel of technique and withal charming in tone. Signor Tomisani still appears to be suffering from a slight cold, but all through the 3rd act he was delightful. We would mention the others did it not seem invidious to single out anyone where all were so uniformly good, and, we may add, so highly appreciated by the audience.
